timeline.message: [#12] renamed overall status, fix for status deserializing

timeline.bodyText: It would be helpful to document, what data is used (or expected to be used) as keys.
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

timeline.bodyText: I guess this mutates the state of landscape? Might be worth to think about an immutable solution with simple input/output.
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

replies.bodyText:
I had in mind to decouple assessment (volatile state) from the landscape (much more static). This could be also worth an extra API endpoint (?)
But then again there is the Assessable interface which encourages to set state on landscape components. Any good idea? @Matthimatiker
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText:
I would need more information to make a qualified decision here.
Separating the static landscape from the state sound reasonable.
Regarding Assessable: What if state was returned instead of assigned?
replies.author: Matthimatiker

replies.bodyText: changed as proposed. Assessment is a separate thing now with its own API and references to landscape components
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText:
This can also be configured on the deserialized objects via annotation, which would make the desired behavior more explicit.
Additionally it would

make data object compatible to any ObjectMapper
make deserialization testable in isolation
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

replies.bodyText: This code was obsolete, sorry.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText:
Interesting. You might consider using @Nullable and @Nonnull annotations on parameters and methods to make the null handling explicit. Additional nice effect: IntelliJ can use these annotations to provide hints when assumptions are violated.
You can find these annotations in the package com.google.code.findbugs.
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

replies.bodyText: org.springframework.lang also provides these annotations. Is findbugs more suitable?
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Is it all JSR-305?
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText:
Is findbugs more suitable?

I never used the annotation from Spring, so I cannot give a comparison.
I like that the annotations from findbugs are purely informational.
In contrast, some similar annotations from Lombok add additional behavior.
replies.author: Matthimatiker

timeline.bodyText: isHigherThan() 👍
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

timeline.bodyText:
I assume this exists because of the lambda function in foreach.
A simple for loop might be easier to use here, avoiding the atomic reference.
Alternatively, using the stream-API might be feasible.
Something like:
Stream.of(
    getStatusValues().stream(),
    getChildren().stream().map(child -> child.getOverallStatus())
)
    .filter(Objects::nonNull)
    // Sort by status value. Is there already a comparator for it?
    .sort()
    .findFirst()
    .orElse(Status.UNKNOWN);
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: bonndan

I often use Objects.requireNonNull() as I am lazy. But this check provides the slightly better message.

timeline.bodyText: Is there a valid case where it is ok to ignore this exception? Doesn't it hide more errors?
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

replies.bodyText:
We do not know the value to assess, which can be anything and can be supplied even by a third party system. So first we try parsing numbers to Double, and it that fails we assume it is a string and is compared against the regex matchers.
One improvement could be throwing an exception if only numeric ranges are defined for the KPI, but then we'd have to handle the exception, and a wrong value from a third party system is not necessarily exceptional.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: 👍  for @Nullable
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

timeline.bodyText:
Can we catch a more specific exception here? Can we check before if the pattern can be compiled?
Is the fallback really the desired behavior? What if I supplied an invalid regex (because of a missing brace etc.), but never intended to apply the contains behavior?
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

replies.bodyText: What would you suggest? Simply warn the user that the regex is wrong?
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: You can pass the exception as last parameter to ensure that it is not completely lost.
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

But yes, that would be better

timeline.bodyText: Did not notice that before, but I would expect highestOf() to return a single item (or an Optional of an item).
timeline.author: Matthimatiker

replies.bodyText: No, for instance a landscape item could have Status.RED concerning security AND health, and neither of them is higher than the other. The method is unused yet, however.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.message: [#114] refactored FullyQualifiedIdentifier: extracted class ItemMatcher for searching purposes
[#12] assessment has separate api and does not change state of landscape component
[#12] kpis are initialised explicitly to catch configuration errors
[#12] Assessable methods not part of public data
[#114] using api data to display item details (wip)
